An intuitive understanding of the slippery slope is problematic. As I learned in a logic class in college, the slippery slope is a type of fallacy, unless there are few steps down the slope and proof that one step is the cause of the next step (and not merely correlated with the next step).

Where's the proof that a "balanced fiscal approach will eventually morph into excessive spending"? That fear is not at all well grounded.

Maybe there is no such thing as excessive austerity --- unless you might be unhappy with unemployment rates exceeding 25%  like they have in Spain, or a triple dip recession, like they have in Great Britain.

I've always found that my fellow Americans have an intuitive understanding of the slippery slope: if we start spending, we won't stop spending; if we are complacent against this threat, we may be complacent against all others. Maybe it's because we live in a society that doesn't believe in moderation too heavily, so we have a deep unconscious fear of excess. I think this is why we could be lied into war (the specter of Saddam was well-established in 2003 and thus it was easy to rail against the lazy peace-loving complacency of hippies) and bamboozled into unnecessary/premature austerity (since we all understand the specter of debt).
There's a (dare I say well-grounded) fear that, whatever the current situation, even a reasonably balanced fiscal approach will eventually morph into excessive spending, whereas it doesn't seem like there can be a such thing as excessive austerity. So maybe we should let this sequestration thing happen so we all see what that actually looks like, and a fear based in reality can replace a fear based on mistaken budgetary analysis.

Elizabeth, I would argue that using money as the motivator, while sad on a personal level, is also a huge advance. It is one of the tools that is allowing us to grow into a vast eusocial meta-organism with great intellectual capability.

Money substitutes for the interpersonal motivational instincts that work only in the context of much smaller groups, e.g., the band or tribe. Money, laws, writing, and the like have all arisen since agriculture made larger groups possible, and are necessary only because of the size of those groups.

Mr. Krugman, you are a Nobel laureate. You must realize that while we do not currently have an insurmountable medium-term deficit problem, there is a future crisis looming if nothing is done to address the entitlement drain. This discussion is anathema to most politicians, but certainly more so to Democrats. Mr. Obama's budget was already set to lower discretionary spending to the lowest level in 50 years, in the absence of the sequester. I assume this was done in order to preserve entitlements at the status quo, but tell me, is that a smart plan for our nation's future? We continue to underinvest in infrastructure, education, and growth-oriented policies to maintain unsustainable levels of entitlement. We are depriving our children of a strong, innovative economy, and a world-class infrastructure and educational system in the name of preserving programs intended to be "insurance against need," not guarantees of a comfortable retirement.

So, please, Mr. Krugman, stop being the guy who sits behind home plate and razzes the opposing team. Use your profound intellect to offer, discuss, and disseminate ideas for solving that problem in a way which is comprehensive, fair, and compassionate. That is the problem we need to address now, because, as I read long ago in one of my Econ 101 texts, "in the long run, we're all dead."
